name: The Monetary Matters Network
title: Market Tumbles On Rosy Jobs Data: Is Inflation Coming Back?
text:
Synopsis
The U.S. job market remains robust, with strong employment data potentially challenging the recession narrative and creating market uncertainty around inflation expectations and potential Federal Reserve rate cuts.

Key Insights
- December jobs report showed 256,000 jobs added, significantly exceeding expectations of 164,000
- Unemployment rate dropped from 4.24% to 4.08%, a substantial 16 basis point decline
- Consumer inflation expectations increased from 2.8% to 3.3% for one-year outlook
- 10-year Treasury yield rose to 4.78%, highest since November 2023
- Oil prices approaching $80 per barrel, potentially impacting consumer inflation expectations
- Market reaction showed stocks and bonds selling off simultaneously on positive economic data
- Federal Reserve minutes suggest inflation might be controlled, but they remain cautious about rate cuts
- Potential Census data adjustment in January jobs report could reveal significant labor market changes
- Market valuations appear elevated, with S&P earnings yield now lower than 10-year Treasury yield
- Speculative excess in markets appears less pronounced compared to 2021-2022 peak
